data.title: Xerox: A 1-Year Review After Q3 2025
data.description:
Sometimes you get them right, and sometimes you get them wrong. In this case, I'm talking about Xerox Holdings Corporation (XRX). As you may know, if you follow my work, about 5-6% I allocate to what we might euphemistically call "troubled" companies. The company that used to be the leader in copying physical documents in a world where physical documents and copies are going out of style faster than horse-drawn carriages certainly qualifies as one such company. The deterioration since my last "BUY" rating for the company certainly speaks for itself, with a negative 65% since that last article a year ago.

I'm very glad that despite my own rating, I elected to mostly go for other risky companies that have not declined as much (though the one I chose has still not beaten the market, speaking about TUI AG (OTCPK:TUIFF)), but at least haven't lost 65%. My own position in Xerox was, as my communication suggested, a "small starter position".

But there's a difference between crashing that amount and being unrecoverable. When it comes to Xerox, in my last article, I made a case for why the company might be able to save ailing Lexmark.

So the question here becomes, because it's been less than 11 months since that piece, is 11 months enough to answer the question of whether the company is going bankrupt?

I would argue that it isn't.

This makes today, on earnings day of the 30th of October, an excellent day for updating my thesis on Xerox. Further, after a 60% decline and more, it might be fair to say that the company has dropped enough for me to be interested in investing after all.

Or am I?

Let's see here.

Xerox—Looking at the potential upside on a forward basis

Xerox is, and remains, the leader in print solutions. That is the company's battle cry and what the company has been focusing on for a long time. However, as mentioned above, this industry is currently declining. Will it see a revitalization? I doubt it. Can Xerox corner what there is left, and what, despite the decline, won't go away?

Printing is unlikely to disappear entirely. Certain things are likely to remain needed in printed form. I belong to the group that believes that printing will not disappear (nor physical material) but exist alongside digital—the question is at what size, and what will the market look at when that transformation is done.

Some arguments for printed/physical material are the physical permanence it offers, security, and in many cases, legal needs of some areas and geographies. We have several things here that can only be done with physical print and copies, and I believe that things have gone too extreme to the digital side anyway. So a drop like the one we're seeing today in 3Q25, or the company's drop since the 2024 period, doesn't really faze me, unless it's based on some very real, fundamental trends.

So what are the fundamental trends?

It's remarkable how similar XRX is to some companies I've invested in at extreme lows. I've invested in companies like Unum Group (UNM), Lincoln National Corporation (LNC), and Intrum AB (publ) (OTCPK:ITJTY) as well as TUI AG. The commonality for every single one of these investments was that at the time of investing, serious analysts and investors were calling for bankruptcy risks. In the case of Intrum, bonds were trading at below 75 cents on the dollar to par. It was perceived as serious in every single case.

Today, Unum is one of my better investments, Intrum is up 380%, and LNC is up more than 100%. I say this not to toot my own horn, but to tell you that I am comfortable with the ups and downs, provided I can understand them.

Xerox is risky. EPS for 2025 is definitely going negative (in my view). The company is B- B-rated (Intrum was worse, was at CCC-). The company still pays a yield, which is something, but it's reduced. Debt is actually high, especially since they bought Lexmark valued at $1.5B, which is now more than 3x the entire market capitalization of the company at a price of below $4/share.

If there is one trait I believe you need as an investor going into something like this (as of today, I'm long Xerox), it's patience. You need to be able to withstand tremendous amounts of pressure.

As you can see above, the company is far from done with anything substantial in its reinvention effort, and recovery is likely to take years. Of course, such an argument is an easy one to make, even if things just keep declining—but in this case, I do believe there is serious reason to expect recovery.

Why?

As I detailed in my original article, the company is likely to be able to leverage some key strengths. One, Lexmark's A4 platform, which is market-leading in the growing core market. It's also likely to be able to capitalize on Lexmark's A3 Models and OEM business, adding Xerox's considerable R&D. Expansion into APAC is likely to drive this further as well.

The company is also shifting by expanding into digital services and IT solutions, both very attractive businesses, with areas like document workflows, intelligent document processing, and the like (though Xerox is likely to encounter substantial competition here).

The reason, dear readers, that I am positive here is because many of the synergies mentioned above are starting to materialize. Revenue is growing, and not in small amounts. It's almost up 25% YoY, and FCF is growing (up over 20%), with debt repayment in full force. The company's adjusted earnings are still impaired, together with operating margins, but again, Xerox is in the absolute middle of a transformation that will take years. No one at the company has told us to expect this to be done at this time. The synergies, as mentioned in the 3Q25, are back-heavy, with most of them coming either in 2026 or 2027. The only thing the company is expecting to manage this year is the initial elimination of double overhead and the like—the heavy stuff comes in the next 36 months.

In retrospect, I did make one big mistake. I shouldn't have gone positive when I did. I should have entered at a "Hold" and waited for some of these issues and likely valuation trends to arrive. The fact that I did not invest a substantial amount of capital yet is no excuse at all—I gave the rating, and this gives responsibility (in my view). Timing of valuation is never easy, and I, of course (obviously), could not expect this, but given the transformations that I've been a part of as an investor, I should have drawn logical links between my tendency to enter too early at times and let this flow to ratings as well.

I didn't.

So let me be clearer this time. If you invest here, be ready for further declines—not guaranteed, but entirely possible. Xerox now has a load of debt that is unenviable, but most of that debt is laden toward the end of 2029-2039—by that time, we should know whether the company has succeeded or not.

The current timeline we have is 2026-2028. For the remainder of the year, the two positive takeaways and expectations we do have are a significant increase in FCF and an operating margin that's likely to trend toward 4-5%. If the company manages this, it will be good. I expect the company in 2026 to manage flat revenue but to be able to go over $300M of gross cost reductions, be able to really start reshaping things here, which should enable an FCF of above $300M per year.

That should start to allow for higher valuations here. My current forecast for 2026 is about a dollar's worth of EPS, compared to about the same level last fiscal, and for that to grow by 30-40% in fiscal 2027. Those improvements are likely, in my view, to come from the aforementioned synergies, growth in IT and digital (but I'm less optimistic on this than other analysts), and continued significant downpayment of debt. Since the M&A, almost every cent has gone to paying that down, the best current use of cash. The entry back into the mid-market for printing through the IJP900 is also something I consider to be likely to boost revenues.

Let's see what we can make of valuation after 3Q25.

Valuation for Xerox in 2025—look at 2026-2027

If you want to invest here, expect a recovery and profit period of no less than 3 years. My own forecast is this. As I said in my previous article, the market considers most of Xerox's sales to be worthless here. Why do I say this?

Because it's currently trading at less than 0.2 to sales, less than 0.7x to revenues, and a book valuation of 0.55x. This is, by the way, despite the fact that analysts are in agreement that revenue is likely to recover close to 2019 levels and above, potentially.

Same thing, by the way, with EBITDA.

So if both sales and earnings are likely to increase in the future, what could the company be worth?

Depends. And this is what makes a company like this interesting. Less than 1-2 years ago, when the company made $1/share in EPS, it traded at a 12-14x P/E. It currently trades at a negative P/E due to negative earnings this year. But if earnings were to recover to even close to this, and the market saw Xerox at a similar valuation, we're talking several hundred percent in returns.

And remember, the forecast you see above is not based on anything outlandish. If the company manages a net savings amount of $300M over the next few years, this would obviously substantially improve the company's cash flow, which in turn would increase net income. That is what I believe the recovery will come from. The $18/share fair value suggested above isn't even unrealistic, if the company manages this, Xerox traded at $18/share less than 2 years ago, and to my mind it was riskier back then because it didn't have the turnaround plan.

I've made it part of my investment approach to invest in distressed value, as I call it. Xerox, as I see it, is distressed value. The company is "down", but it's getting back up. I don't see any clear risk for bankruptcy or issues. The credit risk is considered high when you look at some bonds out there (try USU98401AE97, for instance), but when you look at what the company manages in EBITDA, revenues, debt payments, and the like, I don't really see the company going bankrupt.

This is a risky business, but if you're comfortable with what I consider "manageable risk," then this is for you. I'm taking and adding a long 0.25% position of my portfolio in Xerox at this time, resulting in a 0.29% position, and I expect a big payoff eventually, well over 100-200%.

My price target was $14/share. I'm cutting it to fair value $12/share at a $1.2/share EPS and a 10x P/E, with an upside of over 200%. My PT is therefore $8/share, but that makes this company a discount at this price.

Risks & Considerations

The market considers Xerox sales "worthless". It now also considers the earnings and most of the other parts of the company worthless, going by the way it's valuing the business. It's trading at less than 0.2x to sales, less than 0.7x to revenues, and less than 0.8x to book. The company's book value at this time is higher than the share price, and at almost $3-4/share, not a small amount more than the share price. With Lexmark, this is even better, and I continue to see the risks being outweighed by the positives.

Print declines and the company not succeeding in the turnaround remain the core risk here. Because this is such a substantial risk at this point, I would be careful investing at all here, unless you really are comfortable with the sort of risk/reward this offers but also requires in terms of patience.

There is a real potential, just like with Intrum, of a capital loss here, but I consider that to be very unlikely based on 3Q25 and the company seeming to move forward with its turnaround plan.

Count me in for now with the following thesis.

Thesis

  • Xerox offers, following the Lexmark deal and 3Q25 results, an attractive play on printing and printing services, as well as related IT. Following this, the company is becoming a vertically integrated producer and service-offering business, which is attractive, if high-risk.
  • I consider Xerox to be exceedingly cheap here, but the company is a speculative investment. However, this is something I am comfortable with, and I'm increasing my position.
  • I give the company an updated PT of $8/share and a fair value target of $12/share, above which I might sell, depending on how quickly it "went there". However, the potential for $18-20 over time is definitely there.

Here are my criteria and how the company fulfills them (italicized).

  • This company is overall qualitative.
  • This company is fundamentally safe/conservative & well-run.
  • This company pays a well-covered dividend.
  • This company is currently cheap.
  • This company has a realistic upside based on earnings growth or multiple expansion/reversion.

The company fulfills 1 out of 3 quality indicators and 2 out of 2 valuation indicators. That means 3/5 "stars" here, which is enough for an attractive thesis for the company. Based on this and a price target of $8/share share, I see a risk/reward-adjusted upside that's attractive enough for me. I give the company a "Buy" rating as of October 2025.

data.title: Impax Global Opportunities Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Performance

The portfolio rose in absolute terms during Q3 but underperformed the MSCI ACWI index. Market concentration and style factors continued to be headwinds for the portfolio as returns have been dominated by AI stocks, cyclical companies and interest rate-sensitive financials, which are expected to benefit from deregulation.

Health Care holdings were the largest detractor. The sector has been under pressure due to US policy announcements aimed at lowering the price of healthcare. It has also proven a source of funds for investors looking to allocate into the AI theme. However, the announcement of a deal to provide lower prescription prices for government-funded Medicaid patients, but not the larger Medicare channel, may be a turning point for the sector as this lifts some of the regulatory overhang and provides greater clarity for research and development spending. This would be positive for the portfolio’s exposure to the drug discovery value chain.

Dynamics in the Financials sector have also worked against the portfolio, as easing of regulation favoured large-cap banks which benefit from an increase in capital market related activity. European regional bank KBC (OTCPK:KBCSY) rallied, but companies that typically deliver more consistent earnings through economic cycles, such as consultant Marsh & McLennan (MMC), have traded lower.

The lack of exposure to commodities within the Materials sector created a relative headwind, whilst sustainable construction materials maker Sika (OTCPK:SXYAY) came under pressure as the European construction market remains sluggish. Within Industrials, concerns over AI potentially disrupting business models were negative for data service providers, though better performance came from companies improving resource efficiency or benefiting from energy management and electricity grid investment.

Consumer Discretionary holdings have been a bright spot with eBay (EBAY), which delivered strong results after management refocussed the business on core platforms, rallying. The portfolio’s auto component company Aptiv (APTV) rebounded from its lows and gained momentum after it announced a divestment that allows it to focus on higher-margin advanced driving applications, Within Information Technology, companies with exposure to AI infrastructure also performed well.

Market overview

Global equities posted strong gains in Q3 2025, supported by resilient macroeconomic conditions, improving corporate earnings, fiscal stimulus and deregulation in the banking sector. However, market dynamics favouring hypergrowth, cyclical and value stocks have created headwinds for investors focused on quality, and market concentration increased over the period.

The passage of the One Big Beautiful Bill (OBBB) in the US was a key catalyst early in the quarter, providing short-term stimulus through extended tax cuts and incentives for domestic reshoring. While concerns linger over its longer-term impact on the US fiscal deficit and inflation, the OBBB helped lift investor sentiment, particularly in large-cap and technology stocks. The US Federal Reserve’s September interest rate cut also helped to support share prices and extend the risk-on rally in equities.

Emerging markets also performed well, buoyed by a weaker US dollar and supportive policy measures in China, which included new renewable energy standards targeting high-emission industries and support for the technology sector.

As we end Q3, US regulatory uncertainty has eased for Health Care stocks with the announcement of a deal between President Trump and drug company Pfizer to lower prescription drug prices for the government-funded Medicaid programme. In the short term, the US government shutdown may weigh on investor sentiment but historically these shutdowns have been resolved with little impact on equity markets.

Despite elevated valuations and increased market concentration, the investment team believe opportunities exist in stocks that have been de-rated despite strong earnings momentum and among companies demonstrating strong secular growth. The investment team remains focused on identifying businesses with durable growth drivers, sound management and attractive relative valuations.

1 First full month since inception. The inception date for Impax Global Opportunities Fund Institutional Class is 06/27/2018 and Investor Class is 06/27/2018. As of 05/01/2025 prospectus, total annual Impax Global Opportunities Fund operating expenses, gross of any fee waivers or reimbursements (excluding Acquired Fund fees and expenses), for Institutional Class and Investor Class shares are 1.08%, 1.33% respectively.

Contributors (absolute basis)

  • Oracle (ORCL)(Systems Software, US) saw its share price surge after it delivered exceptionally strong growth and order forecasts. The company is benefitting from sustained demand for its cloud infrastructure platform and AI-powered applications. During the period, a US$500bn project was announced with OpenAI and Softbank to build five new AI data centres in the US.
  • Nvidia (NVDA)(Semiconductors, US) outperformed during the period as investors rewarded the chip maker’s robust demand outlook driven by surging capital expenditures from ‘hyperscale’ data centre operators.
  • TE Connectivity (TEL)(Electronic Manufacturing Services, US) generated strong performance in Q3, as faster-than-expected data centre revenue and margin expansion from their Industrial Solutions segment facilitated very strong quarterly results.

Detractors (absolute basis)

  • London Stock Exchange (OTCPK:LDNXF)(Financial Exchanges & Data, UK) has been impacted by concerns that AI may disrupt its Data & Analytics business model which provides investment solutions, risk tools and wealth & enterprise tools. London Stock Exchange is integrating AI into its own business model and believes that the business is defendable as it is based on real-time data, which is hard to replicated with AI, and customers operate within a regulated framework and need to rely on a trusted, verifiable source.
  • Alcon (ALC)(Health Care Supplies, Switzerland) traded lower after Q2 equipment sales for eye surgery were softer than expected. Management indicated orders for its new system ‘Unity’ remain robust, but its launch is being deliberately phased to allow time to train eye surgeons. It will take time to convert these orders to installations and sales, however there should be an acceleration in the second half of the year.
  • Intuitive Surgical (ISRG)(Health Care Equipment, US) has been weak due to news that a competitor is providing refurbished and repurposed instruments at lower prices. However, Intuitive believes price is only one component customers consider, with reliability, security of supply, accuracy and innovation also factors in decision making. Meanwhile, the market for surgical robotics continues to expand with new applications in areas such as cardiac surgery.

Outlook

The market has gone through another period of extreme concentration, with investors’ focus returning heavily to the AI theme and more cyclical or ‘hypergrowth’ stocks. This has resulted in a de-rating of many companies that the investment team believes continue to deliver strong fundamental performance and offer compelling structural growth.

For example, within Health Care, the portfolio is focussed on companies providing solutions which reduce the time or cost of drug development or improve patient outcomes through innovative products and services. The headwinds which have impacted the sector may now have reached a peak, leading investors to re-examine their appetite for these companies given the clear strength of sector tailwinds such as innovation of treatments and ageing populations.

Within Financials, the portfolio holds companies that are improving access to finance, and businesses which offer greater operational consistency such as data analytics, payment processors and financials consultancy businesses, rather than cyclical, leveraged 'balance sheet' financials. While these stocks are currently out of favour, we believe they remain well placed to benefit from structural growth and deliver superior long-term returns.

Finally, the portfolio retains holdings in a range of companies that the team sees as able to capture either revenue or cost opportunities through implementing AI innovation into their operations. Some of these stocks have been under pressure as investors anticipate disruption to their business models, while our investment team expects these companies, which include recruitment platforms, semiconductor chip designers and stock exchange operators, to benefit from their investments.

The investment team’s focus remains on finding companies with compelling structural growth, with quality characteristics at reasonable valuations. The team believes that the portfolio offers truly diversified exposure to multiple powerful trends across both environmental and social sustainability opportunities.

Fund overview

Impax Global Opportunities Fund is a long-only all-cap global equities strategy that invests in high quality companies with sustainability tailwinds.

Portfolio managers

revealing how much profit a company generates with the money shareholders have invested.

Beta explains common variations in stock returns due to different stock sensitivities to the market relative to its underlying benchmark for the current period, not historical. A beta for a benchmark is 1.00: A beta greater than 1.00 indicates above average volatility and risk.

Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria are a set of standards for a company’s operations that socially conscious investors use to screen potential investments. Environmental criteria consider how a company performs as a steward of nature. Social criteria examine how it manages relationships with employees, suppliers, customers, and the communities where it operates. Governance deals with a company’s leadership, executive pay, audits, internal controls, and shareholder rights.
